Nous nous intéressons aux productions culturelles de la diaspora sénégalaise en France, en particulier musicales et cinématographiques. Nous avons constaté que de nombreux artistes du pays se sont fait connaître via les réseaux de la diaspora et leur circuits de financement avant d'être connus dans leur propre pays. Nous nous demandons si les productions culturelles panafricaines et décoloniales de cette diaspora sont consciemment écrites dans le but d'être diffusées au Sénégal, plus qu'en France, et de participer à une décolonisation esthétique du pays.

C'est une mauvaise problématique même si l'idée est là. Nous essayons de comprendre les dynamiques de légitimation, de reconnaissance et de construction des productions musicales et cinématographiques de la diaspora. Nous utiliserons comme méthode dans notre travail de recherche des interviews de ces artistes.

réplique ça : lambda_C <- function(x,delta,theta) {\r
 y <- ((1-x)/x)^((1+theta)/theta)\r
 z <- 1+y*delta\r
 return(1/z)\r
}\r
#\r
lambda_min <- function(delta,theta) 1/(1+delta^(-theta))\r
#\r
chi_U <- lambda_min # new name\r
#\r
#analytic form for unconstrained cost function.\r
C_min <- function(delta,theta) { \r
 index <- (1+delta^(-theta))^(-1/theta)\r
 return(index)\r
}\r
#\r
C_comply <- function(R,delta,theta) {\r
 k <- (1+theta)/theta\r
 R^k +delta*(1-R)^k\r
}\r
#\r
C.tilde <- function(R,delta,theta) {\r
 cons <- R > lambda_min(delta=delta,theta = theta) \r
 y <- cons * C_comply(R,delta=delta,theta = theta)/C_min(delta=delta,theta = theta) +1-cons\r
 return(y)\r
}\r

réplique les fonctions suivantes : #functions for delta heterogeneity only ====\r
CDF <- function(x,mu,sigma) plnorm(x,meanlog=mu,sdlog=sigma)\r
#PDF <- function(x,mu=0,sigma=0.2) dnorm(log(x),mean=mu,sd=sigma) normal\r
PDF <- function(x,mu,sigma) dlnorm(x,meanlog=mu,sdlog=sigma) #lognormal pdf of delta\r
integrand <- function(x,mu,sigma,theta) lambda_min(delta=x,theta=theta)*PDF(x,mu=mu,sigma=sigma)\r
integral.low <- function(x,mu,sigma,theta) integrate(integrand,lower=1e-5,upper=x,mu=mu,sigma=sigma,theta=theta)$val # log normal so start near zero\r
integral.high <- function(x,mu,sigma,theta,delta_upper=Inf) integrate(integrand,lower=x,upper=delta_upper,mu=mu,sigma=sigma,theta=theta)$val...

function lambda_bar_noAC(R, tau, theta, mu, sigma)\r
 dm = delta_max(tau, theta)\r
 dc = min(delta_circ(R, theta), dm)\r
 ds = delta_star(R, tau, theta)\r
 a = R * (CDF(dc, mu, sigma) - CDF(ds, mu, sigma))\r
 b = integral_low(ds, mu, sigma, theta)\r
 c = integral_high(dc, mu, sigma, theta, delta_upper=dm)\r
 return (a + b + c) / CDF(dm, mu, sigma)\r
endprintln("lambda_bar_noAC: ", lambda_bar_noAC(R, tau, theta, mu, sigma))

Each candidate needed the support of at least 10 MPs to get on to the ballot, including a proposer and seconder. MPs could nominate only one candidate per round of voting.\r
\r
This was a much lower bar than during the last leadership election in 2022, when hopefuls needed the backing of 100 MPs. Mr Sunak was the only one to enter the race with that level of support and so became the party leader.\r
\r
There are currently 121 Tory MPs, but those who are also whips or sit on the executive of the backbench 1922 Committee could not nominate a candidate.\r
\r
Applicants were also told they would each need to raise £200,000 ...

Who decides which candidate will become the next Tory leader?\r
Conservative members are casting their vote between 15 October and 31 October to decide the winner.\r
\r
They are making their choice via secure online voting, though this system has previously been criticised for its susceptibility to hackers and rogue state interference.\r
\r
In recent years, party members have tended to pick the more right-wing candidate of the final two. In the first of two leadership elections in 2022, Mr Sunak consistently won more support from MPs than Liz Truss during each round before party members ultimately chose Ms Truss.\r
\r
To be eligible to vote, party members must have been active for 90 days...

To reiterate partisan media media bias occurs, if the coverage of given political party statistically significantly deviates from their balanced coverage, as mandated by their electoral share and measure through the respective bias gap.

Across all political parties, Die Grünen seem to be political talk shows darling, receiving a consistent, strong, significant and positive discourse- and participation visibility bias, as well as favorable tonality

In terms of discourse visibility, Die Grünen received a strong and significant overrepresentation in discourse of 8.7% in 2017 - 2021 relative to their electoral strength, even further increasing to significant 10.2% in 2021 to 2025. Similarly, if less pronounced, Die Grünen also received a significant overrepresentation as talk show guests of 4.4% between 2017 to 2021 and 5.3% between 2021 and 2025. Thus, - abstaining from any causal claim - following high discourse visibility and participation visibility in 2017 - 2021 in political talk shows, Die Grünen gained a spot in the coalition, and further increased their political talk show visibility during incumbency. Further, Die Grünen cons...

Qualification of these findings by plotting each gap by time-bin highlights strong fluctuations, with gaps quickly moving by up to 15% coverage. This first suggests that - different than for Die Linke - that visibility salience for Die Grünen depends more on issue salience, or other factors such as scandals etc. This might be interesting to analyze in further research. Further, these fluctuations also illustrate that the average bias per election period analysis is limited - given that fluctuations occur within electoral temporals, not necessarily caused by it. Yet, the finding that die Grüne consistently receives positive media partisan bias holds.

\tBetween 2017 and 2021, the SPD received balanced media coverage in both discourse visibility and participation visibility (see table xyz). Discourse mentions closely matched their electoral share...

The CDU/CSU’s political talk show presence reflects a clear incumbency effect across visibility dimensions.
In terms of discourse visibility, CDU/CSU benefited from a strong and statistically significant overrepresentation of +6.5% during their chancellorship in the 2017–2021 period. This aligns with an incumbency bonus in media attention. After transitioning to the opposition, this trend reversed: between 2021 and 2025, CDU/CSU experienced a significant underrepresentation of –5.1% in talk show discourse.
Regarding participation visibility, CDU/CSU maintained balanced guest presence in the 2017–2021 period (0.01), but this dropped to a significant underrepresentation of –3.8% between 202...

Analyzing the evolution of each dimension of partisan media coverage, reveals that participation is remarkably stable, evolving strongly incremental (while being significantly negative while in opposition) - e.g. being in a range of 0.05. This suggests a formalized media mechanism. Discourse visibility gap, on the other hand reflects more fluctuations, interestingly inversely related to tonality in the period from 2021 to 2025, suggesting that having a positive tonality is linked with not being mentioned too much in discourse and vice verca.- Generally the fluctuations are in a more narrow range than for partys like die Grüne, indicating more stability

The FDP’s media presence in political talk shows reveals a clear incumbency effect, marked by increased visibility and more balanced tone during its time in government.
The FDP exhibits a modest discourse visibility shift that aligns with its role in government. Between 2017–2021, the party was slightly but significantly underrepresented in political discourse (–2.5%). In contrast, during its time as a governing coalition partner from 2021–2025, the FDP experienced a consistent and statistically significant overrepresentation of +2.9%.
\tIn terms of direct presence on talk shows, the FDP moved from being significantly underrepresented between 2017–2021 (–5%) to significantly overrepresent...

Analyzing the evolution of each kind of bias gap (see figure xyz), suggests that for the FDP discourse and participation gaps tend to move together - an increase or decrease in one being correlated with an increase or decrease in the other. Further it is notable that - compared to the other parties - discourse and participation visibility tend to develop rather gradually - similarly to the other smaller parties. Finally it is notable that the tonality gap is almost always lower than discourse or participation visibility.

Overall, the AfD is statistically significantly underrepresented in political talk show discourse and participation, and is consistently portrayed in a negative light.
In terms of discourse visibility, the AfD exhibited a significant underrepresentation of –6.6% in the 2017–2021 period. Notably, it is the only party to display a clear and continuous shift from negative to positive discourse visibility during the 2021–2025 electoral term, marking a substantial evolution in its treatment within political talk show discourse. To assess this shift more precisely, a weighted t-test was conducted for each half of the 2021–2025 period. While more sophisticated techniques like segmented regressio...

In Germany, too, academic research on linking political talk shows with political and sociological outcomes has been sparse. Some literature has focused on qualitatively evaluating whether political talk show coverage fulfills normative ideals of political education and public deliberation, often grounded in Habermasian theory (Kade, 2003; Wagner, 2008; Kessler & Lachenmaier, 2017). Conclusions resolve around the lines that political talk-shows do fulfil normative criteria of steering public interest towards important topics and providing different viewpoints, while criticising the subjectivity, conflict and entertainment focus of political talk-shows (Kade, 2003; Wagner, 2008). Notably -...

In the German context, a political talk show is a discussion-based format of televised political communication, broadcasted at least weekly on Public Service Media (PSM), in which a fixed moderator engages with guests - predominantly politicians and experts - to debate and interpret current political and societal issues (Kessler & Lachenmaier, 2017). The dialogical nature of political talk shows thus demarcates them from other media, such as broadcasting news or newspaper coverage. Audiences directly experience political discourse, rather than consuming a synthesis. Despite their widespread reach and persistent relevance - 28% of Germans reporting interest in political talk shows - research has rarely considered them in empirical analyses. This is puzzling, given their central role in shaping political information and discourse in Germany.

Research has used terms such as “media bias”, “partisan media bias”, and “political balance” to assess whether media favour some political actors over others (Hopmann et al., 2012). This study uses the term partisan media bias. Partisan media bias refers to media outlets being more likely to cover (messages from) some political actors rather than others (Haselmayer et al., 2017; Stevenson et al., 1973). More narrowly, partisan media bias tends to be defined as willful and systematic favoring of one party over the other (Castro, 2021; Eberl et al., 2018).

Second, to measure tonality bias I compute a Tonality Score for each party-year combination. To do so, I subtract all negative (N) from positive (P) party mentions and divide this by the sum of P and N in a year t. I only include sentiments of party mentions in a year that exceed a 0.7 probability threshold. The tonality score thus ranges from -1 to +1, where +1 indicates only positive mentions, -1 only negative mentions, and 0 balanced coverage. The tonality index thus provides a bounded, directional tonality score for each party at time t. Neutral mentions are excluded, assuming they do not influence tonality effects. Formalized: 

Tonality Scorex, t=Px, t-Nx,tPx, t+Nx, t

 return pd.Series({"t_stat": t_stat, "p_value": p_value, "mean_gap": data[gap_column].mean(), "n": len(data)})

Although we can observe how topic representations are different from one time to another, the
topic representation at timestep t is independent of
timestep t-1. As a result, this dynamic representation of topics might not result in linearly evolving
topics. When we expect linearly evolving topics,
we assume that a topic representation at timestep t
depends on the topic representation at timestep t-1.

Thesis - Draft Proposal 

Research Topic & Research Question

While much research in the social sciences has relied on Latent Dirichlet Analysis (LDA) (Vayansky & Kumar, 2020; Egger & Yu, 2022) - originally proposed by Blei et al. (2013) - this research employs Grootendorsts (2022) transformer-based BERTopic. LDA is a generative probabilistic model, extracting latent variables from text data. It relies on bag-of-words representation, thus neglecting word-order, syntactic structure and context (Vayansky & Kumar, 2020). This means that LDA does not capture semantic meaning. BERTopic overcomes this limitation, as it relies on text-embedding. Here, word-and sentence vector representations are generated (Grootendorst, 2022), meaning that text used in sim...

In the media partisan bias literature, visibility refers to how frequently political actors are mentioned in media coverage. Visibility bias occurs when political parties systematically receive an undue amount of attention relative to a normative benchmark of political balance (Eberl et al., 2017). This form of bias is strictly quantitative: it considers how often a political actor is mentioned, irrespective of how they are portrayed.

The literature distinguishes between three subcategories of partisan media bias, namely (1) visibility bias, (2) tonality bias, and (3) agenda bias (e.g., Hoppman et al., 2012b; Eberl et al., 2017; Castro, 2021). This research will focus on analyzing the prevalence of visibility and tonality bias in German talk shows over time. Please summarize the limitations: In social sciences, most researchers have used Latent Dirichlet Analysis (LDA) (Vayansky & Kumar, 2020; Egger & Yu, 2022), originally proposed by Blei et al., (2003). LDA is a generative probabilistic model to extract latent variables from a large dataset, assuming that documents are a mix of topics, where each topic is a distribution of words (Bayansky & Kumar, 2020). While LDA is adaptable to be joined with other models and can be tuned and performed in various ways, it has two general key limitations: First, the number of topics is fixed-ante [ELAB] (Vayansky & Kumar, 2020). Second, LDA assumes that topics are independent of each other, the “bag-of-wor...
Ekaborate: LDA is a generative probabilistic model, extracting latent variables from text data. It assumes that a document is a mix of topics > bag of words

It incorporates dynamic topic modeling, with options to consider different times as independent or dependent of each other, making it possible to track evolutions of topics (Grootendorst, 2022). It is useful that BERTopic first creates global representations of topics, regardless of their temporal nature, before developing local representation. This is done by multiplying the term frequency of documents at timestep i with the pre-calculated IDF global IDF value (Grootendorst, 2022). Importantly, this can be done without embedding, leading to fast computation. Further, the same process can be applied to other meta-data, making topical comparison across Talk Shows convenient.  1. Your Visibility Gaps Are Calculated at the Episode Level
You're calculating the discourse visibility share per episode, then merging it with timebin-level averages of MS and PS shares. This creates a mismatch in granularity:

discourse_visibility_share: Calculated per episode (Title)

MS Share and PS Share: Averaged per timebin and party

Some parties only appear in more political episodes

Mention distribution across timebins is uneven

Mean Absolute Error (MAE):
Average of the absolute differences between predicted and actual values
MAE = 1/Nt=1N|yT-y|

Mean Squared Error (MSE) (EXAM)
Average of the squared differences (as a measure of distance) between predicted and actual values, penalising larger errors more heavily
MSE = 1/Nt=1N(y-y)^2

The (training or validation) loss function to measure the models predictions:
> Measures how well the model's predictions match the true labels (-> e.g. language application?). 
> Mathematical way to quantify the error of difference between the predicted output and the actual target
> The goal of training is to minimise this loss. 
Lower loss indicates better model performance, training is about reducing the loss as much as possible
Overfitting in loss functions

Evaluating partisan participation visibility in political talk-shows requires collecting talk-show guests and their political affiliation. This requires (1) identifying guests in political talk shows, and (2) identifying their political affiliation. This is a difficult task, as many names are mentioned in political talk shows, and determining the political affiliation of thousands of guests manually is a meticulous task exceeding the scope of this research. I thus limited myself to identifying politicians in Germany, out of feasibility. This follows the rationale that qualitative assessments of talk-show transcripts has shown that in the introduction of talk-shows the moderator introduces...

Provide critical feedback:

Partisan partisan visibility occurs if a political party is systematically over or underrepresented among talk show guests, as compared to a notion of balanced representation. It thus relates to the amount of direct coverage that representatives of political parties receive. 
Data Collection
Evaluating partisan participation visibility in political talk shows requires identifying both talk show guests and their political affiliation. This involves two major challenges:
Extracting names of participations from talk show meta data
Linking them to formal partisan affiliations
As manually determining the party affiliation of thousands of named individuals mentioned ...

Provide feedback:

Methods & Operationalization

First, to assess the extent to which political talk shows exhibit partisan media bias, this section outlines the respective operationalizations of (1) discourse visibility bias, (2) participation visibility bias, and (3) tonality bias. Special attention will be put on their evolution over time, given the availability of a longitudinal dataset of political talk show transcripts from September 2013 to February 2025. Thus, the dataset spans three election periods. The inclusion criteria for political parties analyzed is that they held representation in the Bundestag at any point during the examined time frame, thus guaranteeing their relevance...

Again, I test whether participation visibility of a given party during a governing period is significantly different from zero (see table xyz for hypothesis).

In line with Eberl et al. (2017) I measure tonality bias as the systematic deviation of each party's specific tonality from the average tonality of all parties, in a time bin.
\tSecond, to measure tonality bias I compute a Tonality Score for each party-year combination. To do so, I subtract all negative (N) from positive (P) party mentions and divide this by the sum of P and N in a year t. I only include sentiments of party mentions in a year that exceed a 0.7 probability threshold. The tonality score thus ranges from -1 to +1, where +1 indicates only positive mentions, -1 only negative mentions, and 0 balanced coverage. The tonality ...

Imrpove phraseing:

T-test is not possible as there are not enough entries per party (even per timebin), and variance is lacking (e.g. only negative ones) in the same, given the high number of neutral sentiments in the one sentence choice.

A t-test is not feasible in the one-sentence context due to the insufficient number of observations per party–timebin combination and the lack of variance, often with only negative mentions recorded (given that the tonality score ignores neutral mentions).

To examine whether the tonality gap fulfils the systematicity condition, thus becoming tonality bias, I compute a one-sample t-test for each party x and year. Formalized, I hypothesize:
H0: Party x’s tone is equal to the mean tone across parties (no tonality bias)
H1: Party x’s tone deviates significantly from the mean (relative tonality bias)

Improve: To identify the tonality of political parties this research identifies the sentiments of political party mentions, that is the tone with which they got mentioned.
Shortly outline some: Sentiment analysis has several limitations [...] and provide citations.

The average tonality of all parties, here, serves as the PS media balance baseline, following Hopmatt et al. (2012b), and is the only balance baseline used here, given difficulties in operationalizing an MS media baseline for tonality.

To measure - and compare - parties specific tonalities deviation from the neutrality PS baseline, I compute the Tonality Gap of party x at time t. A positive gap means that party x is treated more favorably than average, while a negative gap indicates the opposite. 

Tonality Gapx, t=Tonality Scorex, t-Tonalityt 
Where, 
Tonality Scorex, t=Px, t-Nx,tPx, t+Nx, t
And,
Tonalityt=1kx=1kTonality Score
For the tonality score, I subtract all negative (N) from positive (P) party mentions and divide this by the sum of P and N in a year t. The tonality score thus - as the tonality gap - ranges from -1 to +1, where +1 indicates only positive mentions, -1 only negative mentions, and 0 balanced covera...

Operationalization
Having extracted the sentiments of the sentence in which political parties are mentioned, this research - in line with Eberl et al. (2017) - measures tonality bias as the systematic deviation of each party’s specific tonality from the average tonality of all parties, in a time bin. 
Balance Operationalization
The average tonality score across all parties is used as the Party System (PS) media balance baseline, following the approach of Hopmann et al. (2012b). This study does not incorporate a Media System (MS) baseline for tonality due to conceptual and operational challenges in defining media-driven expectations of tone across political actors.
\tFollowing a PS perspec...

Analysis
To analyze differences in party tonality, this research (descriptively) explores the evolution of tonality over time. Statistical testing is not feasible, as in the one-sentence context window, there are only a limited number of observations per party-time combination, as well as occasionally absence of variance - often with only negative mentions recorded - as neutral mentions are excluded from the tonality score.

One overarching limitation - next to the ones discussed in the corresponding sections - of this operationalization of tonality bias is, that it focuses on how political parties are discussed but not how they speak themselves during political talk shows. Assessing the tonality of political actors' own speech—especially in relation to specific topics—would offer valuable insights into strategic communication and polarization dynamics. However, this would require accurate speaker diarization and topic attribution, which remain outside the scope of this study but might be interesting to analyse for future research.

Sentiment Analysis
To assess the tonality of political parties, this research uses the XLM Roberta-German Sentiment model to identify the sentiment of the sentence surrounding party mentions, operationalized as the emotional tone with which each party is discussed.

import numpy as np

def weighted_t_test(values, weights, mu=0):
 """Performs a weighted one-sample t-test."""
 values, weights = np.array(values), np.array(weights)

 # Weighted mean
 weighted_mean = np.average(values, weights=weights)

 # Weighted variance
 variance = np.average((values - weighted_mean)**2, weights=weights)
 std_dev = np.sqrt(variance)

 # Effective sample size

 # T-statistic
 t_stat = (weighted_mean - mu) / (std_dev / np.sqrt(n_eff)) if std_dev != 0 else np.nan

Notwithstanding this remarkable public reaction, the FCC proposed a radical revision for all but the dual network rule. The audience reach threshold in the national television rule would be increased to 45 per cent. The common ownership rule would be changed to continue control of two stations in markets with fewer than 17 stations but to allow three stations in bigger markets, provided only one of those three was among the highest rating four. Cross-ownership rules would also be relaxed, allowing no restrictions in large markets of nine or more television stations, with graduated combinations of newspaper, television and radio in intermediate markets with more than three stations, where ...

In a democratic system, **formal institutions** are the established structures and codified rules that define and regulate the functioning of the government and its interactions with citizens. These institutions are typically enshrined in legal documents such as constitutions, statutes, and official regulations. Key components include:

* **Constitution**: The supreme legal document outlining the fundamental principles, structures, and functions of the government, as well as the rights and duties of citizens.
 
* **Legislature**: The elected body responsible for creating, amending, and repealing laws. It represents the populace and ensures that legislation reflects the will of the people....

Civil society encompasses a broad spectrum of organizations and associations that operate independently from the government and the private sector. These entities include non-governmental organizations (NGOs), community groups, faith-based organizations, professional associations, and advocacy groups. While some of these organizations are formally structured with official recognition and legal status, others function informally without formal registration or legal standing. [Civil Society Commission](https://civilsocietycommission.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/What-is-civil-society.pdf)
